title: New Daily Persistent Headache (NDPH)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of new daily persistent headache (NDPH) as defined by ICHD-3 criteria. Includes comprehensive secondary headache exclusion, subtype characterization (migraine-like vs tension-like), and treatment approaches. Covers ED evaluation for secondary headache mimics, inpatient bridge therapy for severe cases, and outpatient chronic management. NDPH is one of the most treatment-refractory primary headache disorders and requires systematic evaluation.

Core Labs (Exclude Secondary Causes).rationale: Infection; anemia; leukemia as secondary cause
Metabolic causes of chronic headache; renal/hepatic function
Giant cell arteritis (if age >50); inflammatory process; vasculitis
Inflammatory markers; complement ESR in GCA screening

Extended Labs (Guided by Clinical Suspic.rationale: Autoimmune/connective tissue disease with secondary headache (SLE, vasculitis)
If CVT suspected (combined with imaging); sensitivity aid
Neurosarcoidosis with chronic headache; pachymeningeal disease
Differentiate bacterial infection from viral/inflammatory if fever present

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Post-viral NDPH onset (common trigger); document temporal association
Rare/Specialized.target: IgM negative (past infection); IgG positive supports post-viral trigger

Rare/Specialized.item: CSF analysis (opening pressure, cells, protein, glucose, cytology, cultures)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Rule out elevated/low ICP, infection, inflammation, carcinomatous meningitis; opening pressure is critical
Rare/Specialized.target: OP 10-25 cm H2O; normal cells, protein, glucose; negative cultures and cytology

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If chronic meningitis suspected (low-grade CSF pleocytosis)

Essential Studies.timing: All NDPH patients; essential to exclude secondary causes
Essential Studies.target: No mass, pachymeningeal enhancement (low CSF pressure or sarcoid), leptomeningeal enhancement (infection/carcinomatous), pituitary pathology, Chiari malformation

Essential Studies.timing: All NDPH patients; cerebral venous thrombosis mimics NDPH
Essential Studies.target: Patent dural sinuses; no thrombosis; no stenosis

Essential Studies.timing: If NDPH onset with neck pain; exclude cervical artery dissection and intracranial vascular abnormality
Essential Studies.target: No dissection; no aneurysm; normal vascular anatomy

Extended Studies.timing: If MRI is normal; measure opening pressure to exclude IIH or low-pressure headache; CSF analysis
Extended Studies.target: Opening pressure 10-25 cm H2O; normal CSF constituents

Extended Studies.timing: If cervicogenic headache component suspected; Chiari malformation evaluation
Extended Studies.target: No Chiari; no cervical disc disease causing headache referral pattern

Extended Studies.timing: ED first-line if MRI not immediately available; rule out hemorrhage, hydrocephalus
Extended Studies.target: No hemorrhage; no hydrocephalus; no mass with shift

Rare/Specialized.timing: If dissection or CVT suspected and MRI/MRA not immediately available
Rare/Specialized.target: No dissection; no CVT; normal vasculature

Rare/Specialized.timing: If RCVS or vasculitis suspected on non-invasive imaging; vasospasm evaluation
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal vasculature; no beading (vasculitis) or multifocal stenosis (RCVS)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If seizure component to headache suspected; migraine aura differential

Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.indication: Severe refractory NDPH; inpatient bridge therapy; Raskin protocol

dosing.instructions: Pre-treat with ondansetron 4 mg IV; then DHE 0.5 mg IV q8h for 3-5 days (Raskin protocol); hold if nausea/vomiting despite antiemetics; max 5 days

Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.contraindications: Coronary artery disease; peripheral vascular disease; uncontrolled HTN; pregnancy; concurrent triptans (24h washout); hepatic/renal failure; hemiplegic or basilar migraine
Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.monitoring: BP; HR; chest pain; nausea; extremity perfusion; liver function

Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.indication: Acute pain relief; occipital predominant pain; bridge to preventive therapy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Nerve blocks (greater occipital nerve block) 2.5 mL 0.5% bupivacaine + 40 mg methylprednisolone Injection

dosing.instructions: Bilateral GON blocks; onset within 30 min; duration days to weeks; can repeat q4-8 weeks
dosing.orderSentence: Nerve blocks (greater occipital nerve block) 2.5 mL 0.5% bupivacaine + 40 mg methylprednisolone Injection

Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.contraindications: Allergy to local anesthetic; infection at injection site; anticoagulation (relative)
Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.monitoring: Pain scores; duration of relief; injection site

Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.indication: Severe inflammatory NDPH; post-viral onset with inflammatory features; short course for bridge

dosing.instructions: 250-500 mg IV daily for 3 days; then oral taper (prednisone 60 mg x3 days, 40 mg x3 days, 20 mg x3 days); one-time pulse, not ongoing

Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.contraindications: Active infection; uncontrolled diabetes; GI bleeding; psychosis history
Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.monitoring: Blood glucose; BP; GI symptoms; mood; sleep

Acute Treatment / Bridge Therapy.indication: Acute pain in ED; short course only

dosing.instructions: 30 mg IV/IM q6h; max 5 days; reduce to 15 mg in elderly

Preventive Treatment — First-Line.indication: NDPH prevention (migraine-like subtype); good evidence for chronic daily headache reduction

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg qHS; increase by 25 mg/week; target 50-100 mg BID; max 200 mg BID; slow titration reduces paresthesia and cognitive side effects

Preventive Treatment — First-Line.contraindications: Kidney stones; metabolic acidosis; pregnancy (teratogenic); narrow-angle glaucoma
Preventive Treatment — First-Line.monitoring: Cognitive effects (word-finding difficulty); paresthesias; weight loss; kidney stones; bicarbonate level

Preventive Treatment — First-Line.indication: NDPH prevention (tension-like subtype); concurrent insomnia or depression

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg qHS; titrate by 10 mg q1-2 weeks; target 50-75 mg qHS; max 150 mg; takes 4-6 weeks for headache prevention effect

Preventive Treatment — First-Line.contraindications: Cardiac arrhythmia; recent MI; concurrent MAOIs; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma
Preventive Treatment — First-Line.monitoring: ECG (if dose >100 mg or cardiac risk); anticholinergic effects; weight gain; sedation

Preventive Treatment — First-Line.indication: NDPH prevention; dual serotonin-norepinephrine mechanism; concurrent depression or anxiety

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5 mg daily for 1 week; increase to 75 mg daily; target 150-225 mg daily; extended-release formulation

Preventive Treatment — First-Line.contraindications: Uncontrolled HTN; concurrent MAOIs; severe hepatic impairment
Preventive Treatment — First-Line.monitoring: BP (dose-dependent HTN); serotonin syndrome risk; withdrawal syndrome if stopped abruptly

Preventive Treatment — First-Line.indication: NDPH with neuropathic pain features; coexisting anxiety; first-line alternative

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; increase by 300 mg q3-5 days; target 300-600 mg TID; max 3600 mg/day

Preventive Treatment — First-Line.indication: NDPH with insomnia; tension-like subtype; medication-sensitive patients

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg qHS; increase by 10 mg q2 weeks; target 25-50 mg qHS; low-dose for headache prevention

Preventive Treatment — First-Line.monitoring: Sedation; weight gain; anticholinergic effects; ECG

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.indication: NDPH with migraine-like features refractory to oral preventives; emerging use in NDPH (off-label)

doseOptions.orderSentence: CGRP monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab) 140 mg SQ

dosing.instructions: Erenumab 70-140 mg SQ monthly; fremanezumab 225 mg SQ monthly or 675 mg quarterly; galcanezumab 240 mg loading then 120 mg monthly; trial 3-6 months
dosing.orderSentence: CGRP monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab) 140 mg SQ

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.monitoring: Headache diary; injection site reactions; constipation (erenumab); BP

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.indication: Refractory NDPH; some case series evidence; Na channel blocker

dosing.instructions: Start 150 mg daily; increase by 150 mg q3 days; target 150 mg TID; max 300 mg TID; obtain baseline ECG

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.contraindications: Cardiac conduction disease; 2nd/3rd degree AV block; hepatic disease
Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.monitoring: ECG (QRS widening, QTc); tremor; GI symptoms; hepatic function

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.indication: NDPH with post-infectious onset; anti-inflammatory mechanism; case series evidence

dosing.instructions: 100 mg BID for 3-6 months; anti-inflammatory and possible anti-CGRP properties; well tolerated

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.monitoring: GI symptoms; photosensitivity; esophagitis (take upright with water)

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.indication: NDPH with migraine-like features; chronic migraine paradigm (>=15 headache days/month)

dosing.instructions: PREEMPT protocol: 31 injection sites across 7 head/neck areas; 5 units per site; follow-up sites at pain areas; trial of at least 2-3 cycles

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.contraindications: Hypersensitivity to botulinum toxin; infection at injection sites; neuromuscular disorder (MG, LEMS)
Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.monitoring: Neck weakness; injection site pain; headache worsening initially; ptosis; response assessment at each cycle

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.indication: Severely refractory NDPH; inpatient pain protocol; growing evidence as bridge therapy

dosing.instructions: 0.1-0.5 mg/kg/hr continuous infusion over 3-5 days; NMDA receptor antagonist; requires cardiac monitoring; perform in specialized headache center or infusion unit

Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.contraindications: Uncontrolled HTN; psychosis; elevated ICP; pregnancy; liver failure
Preventive Treatment — Second-Line/Refra.monitoring: BP; HR; dissociative symptoms; nausea; liver enzymes; psychomimetic effects; continuous monitoring

Referrals & Consults.item: Headache specialist/neurologist for comprehensive NDPH evaluation, secondary cause exclusion, and treatment planning — NDPH is among the most challenging headache disorders and benefits from specialist management

Pain psychology/behavioral medicine for cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), biofeedback, relaxation training, and acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) — psychological approaches are important given refractory nature of NDPH
Physical therapy for cervicogenic component assessment, myofascial trigger point therapy, posture correction, and aerobic exercise program
Psychiatry if significant comorbid depression or anxiety; NDPH is psychologically devastating and requires mental health support

Patient Instructions.item: NDPH is a recognized medical condition — the headache is real, it has a name, and research is ongoing; validation is an important part of treatment
Keep a detailed headache diary recording daily pain intensity (0-10), headache character (pulsating, pressing), associated symptoms, medications taken, and functional impact
Avoid medication overuse (taking acute pain medications >10-15 days/month) — this can cause medication overuse headache superimposed on NDPH, making it even harder to treat
Maintain regular sleep schedule (consistent bed and wake times), eat regular meals, exercise 30 minutes daily, and stay well hydrated — lifestyle regularity improves headache management
Understand that NDPH is often treatment-resistant and may require trials of multiple medications and combinations before finding effective treatment; set realistic expectations
A subset of NDPH patients (15-20%) experience spontaneous resolution within months to a few years; this possibility provides hope even during refractory periods

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise 30-45 minutes, 5 days/week — evidence supports exercise as beneficial for chronic headache reduction
Stress management: CBT, mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), biofeedback, relaxation techniques — psychological approaches are essential given the chronic nature
Avoid known migraine triggers if migraine-like subtype: alcohol, processed foods, irregular meals, sleep deprivation, excessive caffeine
Limit caffeine to <=200 mg/day (2 cups coffee) and keep intake consistent; avoid abrupt caffeine withdrawal
Maintain healthy weight — obesity is a risk factor for headache chronification

differential.features: History of pre-existing episodic migraine that gradually increased in frequency; no clear-cut onset date; unlike NDPH which starts de novo at high frequency
differential.tests: Headache history documenting prior episodic migraine; ICHD-3 criteria for chronic migraine (>=15 days/month, >=8 with migrainous features)

differential.features: Daily headache in setting of frequent acute medication use (>=10-15 days/month); headache improves with withdrawal of overused medication; may coexist with NDPH
differential.tests: Medication diary showing overuse; 2-month washout trial; headache improvement after withdrawal

differential.features: Headache with papilledema; pulsatile tinnitus; visual obscurations; worse with Valsalva; typically overweight women of childbearing age
differential.tests: Fundoscopy (papilledema); LP opening pressure >25 cm H2O; MRI (empty sella, transverse sinus stenosis, optic nerve sheath distention)

differential.features: Orthostatic headache (dramatically worse upright, better lying down); subdural collections; may have history of LP, epidural, or connective tissue disease
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (pachymeningeal enhancement, subdural collections, brain sagging); LP opening pressure <6 cm H2O; CT myelogram to find CSF leak

differential.features: Headache with papilledema, seizures, or focal deficit; risk factors (OCP, pregnancy, thrombophilia, infection)
differential.tests: MRV showing thrombosis; D-dimer (sensitivity but not specificity); hypercoagulable workup

differential.features: Headache with low-grade fever, cranial neuropathy, cognitive change; CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: LP: elevated protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis; cultures (TB, fungal, bacterial); cytology; MRI enhancement

differential.features: Unilateral headache provoked by neck movement or sustained posture; ipsilateral neck/shoulder pain; reduced cervical ROM
differential.tests: Clinical exam (provoked by neck maneuvers); diagnostic cervical medial branch block; MRI cervical spine

differential.features: Strictly unilateral continuous headache with cranial autonomic features (tearing, rhinorrhea, ptosis) and absolute response to indomethacin
differential.tests: Indomethacin trial (75-225 mg/day): COMPLETE response is diagnostic; partial response → not HC

differential.features: Daily headache developing within 7 days of head trauma or regaining consciousness after trauma; similar phenotype to NDPH but temporal relationship to injury
differential.tests: History of head trauma; onset within 7 days; may resolve within 3-12 months or persist

evidence.recommendation: ICHD-3 diagnostic criteria for new daily persistent headache (4.10)
NDPH is a primary headache disorder defined by daily and unremitting headache from onset, distinctly remembered
Post-infectious trigger is common; EBV and other viral infections identified in many NDPH series
Topiramate has best available evidence among preventives for chronic daily headache
CGRP monoclonal antibodies show promise for treatment-refractory NDPH (case series)
IV DHE (Raskin protocol) is effective bridge therapy for refractory chronic daily headache
Mexiletine has shown benefit in refractory NDPH in small series
OnabotulinumtoxinA (PREEMPT protocol) for chronic migraine; extrapolated to NDPH with migrainous features
evidence.evidenceLevel: Class I, Level A (for CM); Class IIb for NDPH

evidence.recommendation: Self-limiting subtype resolves in approximately 15-20% of cases

monitoring.action: Medication adjustment; change preventive class; consider advanced therapies; psychological support
Counsel on medication overuse; set strict limits; consider detoxification if overusing
Intensify treatment if worsening disability; behavioral health referral; employment/disability support

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; 2-4 weeks after dose change
monitoring.action: Dose adjustment; switch medication class; maximize tolerability

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; with any headache character change
monitoring.action: If papilledema develops: urgent LP, ophthalmology, evaluate for IIH or secondary cause
Supplement with bicarbonate; discontinue topiramate if persistent acidosis or stones

disposition.criteria: Secondary causes excluded by imaging and labs; pain managed; outpatient neurology/headache specialist follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks; medication overuse counseling
Awaiting MRI/MRV; LP planned for opening pressure; IV pain management needed

DHE IV protocol (Raskin protocol, 3-5 days); ketamine infusion for refractory NDPH; LP showing abnormality requiring inpatient treatment; steroid pulse therapy; severe acute worsening with new red flags
Rare; only if concurrent CVT with hemorrhagic infarction, severe cerebral edema, or critical illness
Initial evaluation: 2-4 weeks; medication titration: q4-6 weeks; stable on preventive: q3 months; injection therapies (nerve blocks, Botox): per schedule
